claim: If you type your PIN number backwards into an ATM, the police will be summoned.

supporting.text: There is no widely documented or mainstream evidence that ATMs are programmed to summon police when a PIN is entered backwards.

attacks.text: There is no widely documented or mainstream evidence that ATMs are programmed to summon police when a PIN is entered backwards.
Some ATMs in high-security areas or specific banks may have experimental or undisclosed security features, including reverse PIN detection.
Even if such features exist, they would be extremely rare and not part of standard ATM software deployments.
Urban legends and anecdotal reports sometimes describe reverse PIN triggering alarms, suggesting the feature might exist in limited cases.
Anecdotal reports lack verifiable evidence and are often debunked as myths or misunderstandings of ATM error messages.

supporting.text: ATM security systems are designed to detect incorrect PIN entries but do not have a specific function to identify reversed PINs as an emergency signal.

attacks.text: ATM security systems are designed to detect incorrect PIN entries but do not have a specific function to identify reversed PINs as an emergency signal.
Some banks may implement custom security measures that include flagging reversed PINs as suspicious activity, potentially alerting authorities.
There is no documented evidence or widespread reports of banks using reversed PIN detection as an emergency alert system.
ATM software is standardized and does not include features for interpreting reversed PINs differently from other incorrect entries.

supporting.text: Banking and financial institutions have not publicly confirmed any feature that links reversed PIN entry to law enforcement alerts.

attacks.text: Banking and financial institutions have not publicly confirmed any feature that links reversed PIN entry to law enforcement alerts.
Some banks have implemented silent alarms triggered by specific PIN sequences, including reversed PINs, as a security measure.
Even if silent alarms exist, reversed PINs are not a standardized or widely adopted method for triggering them.
Law enforcement agencies have confirmed the use of reversed PINs as a distress signal in certain jurisdictions.
Such confirmations are anecdotal and not part of any official banking or law enforcement policy.

supporting.text: Standard ATM software focuses on fraud prevention through transaction monitoring, not by triggering police response based on PIN entry patterns.

attacks.text: Standard ATM software focuses on fraud prevention through transaction monitoring, not by triggering police response based on PIN entry patterns.
Some banks have implemented emergency PIN reversal features to alert authorities in cases of duress.
Emergency PIN reversal features are rare and not standardized across ATM software platforms.
ATM fraud detection systems may flag repeated failed PIN attempts, potentially leading to police notification.
Flagging failed attempts is different from triggering police response for reversed PIN entry specifically.

supporting.text: If such a feature existed, it would likely be publicly documented in banking security guidelines or ATM operation manuals, which it is not.

attacks.text: If such a feature existed, it would likely be publicly documented in banking security guidelines or ATM operation manuals, which it is not.
Some security features are intentionally undocumented to prevent exploitation by criminals.
Undocumented security features would still likely be known to law enforcement or banking regulators, but there is no evidence of such a feature being used.
The absence of documentation does not prove the absence of the feature, as banks may withhold certain details for security reasons.
If banks withheld such a critical security feature, it would likely leak over time due to whistleblowers or investigative journalism, yet no such leaks exist.
